awd_titl_txt: Interaction Mechanics of a Stiff Hollow Tube Penetrating a Soft Nonlinear Material
awd_abstract_narration:
Recently there has been a substantial and growing interest in the medical community to develop next-generation surgical needles to reduce tissue damage during percutaneous interventional procedures. Innovative solutions to the challenge may be found in nature. Insects such as honeybees, mosquitos, and wasps have sophisticated stinger structures and stinging mechanisms, which help them to effectively steer their stingers to specific targets. This award supports fundamental research to study these insertion mechanisms and to obtain knowledge on insertion mechanics as a basis for designing bioinspired surgical needles. Innovative needling devices employing nature-inspired insertion mechanisms will enhance the effectiveness of various existing percutaneous procedures and improve the patients' comfort, and therefore benefit a wide range of medical diagnoses and treatments including those related to cancers. In addition, bioinspired needles with improved controllability can also help develop new medical procedures for biopsy, drug delivery, brain surgery, and many other percutaneous procedures. Through the course of the research work, this project also aims to educate the next generation of scientists and engineers by mentorship and development of new educational materials. Moreover, this project will enhance the engagement of underrepresented groups and women in STEM education and training, and disseminate the state-of-the-art knowledge obtained from research activities to a broad range of audience including the general public and high school students in a variety of public forums such as science fairs, open house events, and summer programs. 

Lack of mechanics-based understanding of bioinspired needle-tissue interactions has been a major obstacle preventing effective design and development of transformative surgery needling technologies. This project will address the challenges in applying bioinspired designs to advanced needling technologies by extending our understanding of mechanical interactions between artificial components (bioinspired needles) and biological systems (soft tissues). Achievement of this goal will be facilitated by understanding the insertion and extraction mechanics of bioinspired needles through experimental studies, studying the effect of manufacturing conditions on the mechanical properties of the needle components, and predicting the insertion behavior using analytical and simulation methods. The outcome of this work will provide novel knowledge on mechanical behavior of bioinspired needle under relevant conditions, and assist development of reliable predictive needle-insertion models for advanced surgeries.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: TEMPLE UNIVERSITY-OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

por.por_cntn:
This NSF project supports the fundamental study of the insertion mechanics of bioinspired needle (stiff and hollow) structures in soft tissue materials by mimicking insect stinger structures and stinging mechanisms through analytical and experimental methods. In developing the bioinspired needles, we investigated stinger structures and stinging mechanisms of insects such as honeybees, mosquitos, and wasps. Our results showed that the developed bioinspired needles can be efficiently controlled for needle steering during insertion in tissues and can result in more effective and less invasive percutaneous procedures. Innovative needle devices employing nature-inspired structures and insertion mechanisms can enhance the effectiveness of various existing percutaneous procedures and improve patient comfort, and therefore benefit a wide range of medical diagnoses and treatments including those related to cancers. In addition, bioinspired needles with improved controllability can also help to develop new medical procedures such as brachytheraphy, cancer biopsy, deep brain stimulation, brain surgeries, and other percutaneous procedures, which are very difficult to perform using current technologies. Specifically, we have made important contributions to improve the performance of surgical needle in the following aspects. 

  • We observed that that the application of the bioinspired features such as needle shape and geometrical modifications and the application of a vibrational needle insertion method reduce the damaging friction force by 11.34% and the damaging insertion force by 26.24%. 
  • We introduced new coatings on surgical needle to decrease the needle insertion force, which is the major contributor of tissue damage. We developed and manufactured coatings on the needle using a combination of of Polydopamine (PDA), Polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE), and Activated Carbon (C). It was observed that the insertion force on bovine kidney tissue can be significantly reduced by 49% using coated needles. Furthermore, a histological study comparing bovine kidney tissue damage resulting from coated and uncoated needles also revealed an average of 39% reduction in tissue damage with the use of coated needles.
  • For more efficient needle steering during insertion in tissues, there is a critical need to accurately predict mechanical forces to minimize the effect of the forces on tissue damage as well as to design better insertion procedures for robotics surgery. We have developed analytical and numerical mechanics models to predict forces at the interface of needle body and tissues. Through experimental and analytical studies, we predicted the cutting force, the deformation force, and the friction force involved during needle insertion. It was observed that the predicted force model only differs about 8% to 23% difference compared with the experimental results. 
  • Additionally, a fundamental understanding of needle tip deflection in tissue is vital for improving the efficiency of needle insertion in reaching the intended targets inside tissue, for example, during drug delivery and biopsy. We developed mathematical mechanics models using a combined approach of the modified Euler-Bernoulli beam elastic foundation theory and experimental procedures. Using our models in predicting the needle deflection during insertion in elastic multi-layered tissues, we discovered that the predicted tip deflections differ by about 9% to 21% compared with the deflections obtained from needle insertion experiments. However, the predicted models incorporating viscoelastic tissue model yield better results. Our results show 3% to 5% difference between the prediction and the experimental results performed in porcine muscle tissue, and 8% to 15% difference when performed in porcine kidney tissue.

In summary, we have successfully gained new fundamental understanding on the effects of needle shape, geometry, and mechanical properties on the insertion effectiveness of bioinspired needle devices that leads enhanced controllability and reduced invasiveness. The research has provided novel knowledge on mechanical behavior of biomimicking needle devices under relevant conditions and will lead to development of reliable predictive needle-insertion models for robotics surgery. Overall, this research has established mechanics-based framework to design needling instrument with innovative biomimicking insertion mechanisms. Furthermore, this project has trained and educated the next generation of scientists and engineers by mentoring undergraduate and graduate students. This project has also attracted participation of underrepresented groups and women in STEM education and training by dissemination of the state-of-the-art knowledge to a broad range of audience including the general public and high school students through a variety of public forums such as technical conferences, science fairs, open house events, and summer programs.

 

 


Last Modified: 04/23/2024
Modified by: Parsaoran Hutapea
por.por_txt_cntn:
This NSF project supports the fundamental study of the insertion mechanics of bioinspired needle (stiff and hollow) structures in soft tissue materials by mimicking insect stinger structures and stinging mechanismsthrough analytical and experimental methods. In developing the bioinspired needles, we investigatedstinger structures and stinging mechanisms of insects such as honeybees, mosquitos, and wasps.Our results showed that the developedbioinspired needles can be efficiently controlled for needle steering during insertion in tissues and can result in more effective and less invasive percutaneous procedures. Innovative needle devices employing nature-inspired structures and insertion mechanisms can enhance the effectiveness of various existing percutaneous procedures and improve patient comfort, and therefore benefit a wide range of medical diagnoses and treatments including those related to cancers. In addition, bioinspired needles with improved controllability can also help to develop new medical procedures such as brachytheraphy, cancer biopsy, deep brain stimulation, brain surgeries, and other percutaneous procedures, which are very difficult to perform using current technologies. Specifically, we have made important contributions to improve the performance of surgical needle in the following aspects.

We observed that that the application of the bioinspired features such as needle shape and geometrical modifications and the application of a vibrational needle insertion method reduce the damaging friction force by 11.34% and the damaging insertion force by 26.24%.
We introduced new coatings on surgical needle to decrease the needle insertion force, which is the major contributor of tissue damage. We developed and manufactured coatings on the needle using a combination of of Polydopamine (PDA), Polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE), and Activated Carbon (C). It was observed that the insertion force on bovine kidney tissue can be significantly reduced by 49% using coated needles. Furthermore, a histological study comparing bovine kidney tissue damage resulting from coated and uncoated needles also revealed an average of 39% reduction in tissue damage with the use of coated needles.
For more efficient needle steering during insertion in tissues, there is a critical need to accurately predict mechanical forces to minimize the effect of the forces on tissue damage as well as to design better insertion procedures for robotics surgery. We have developed analytical and numerical mechanics models to predict forces at the interface of needle body and tissues. Through experimental and analytical studies, we predicted the cutting force, the deformation force, and the friction force involved during needle insertion. It was observed that the predicted force model only differs about 8% to 23% difference compared with the experimental results.
Additionally, a fundamental understanding of needle tip deflection in tissue is vital for improving the efficiency of needle insertion in reaching the intended targets inside tissue, for example, during drug delivery and biopsy. We developed mathematical mechanics models using a combined approach of the modified Euler-Bernoulli beam elastic foundation theory and experimental procedures. Using our models in predicting the needle deflection during insertion in elastic multi-layered tissues, we discovered that the predicted tip deflections differ by about 9% to 21% compared with the deflections obtained from needle insertion experiments. However, the predicted models incorporating viscoelastic tissue model yield better results. Our results show 3% to 5% difference between the prediction and the experimental results performed in porcine muscle tissue, and 8% to 15% difference when performed in porcine kidney tissue.



In summary, we have successfully gained new fundamental understanding on the effects of needle shape, geometry, and mechanical properties on the insertion effectiveness of bioinspired needle devices that leads enhanced controllability and reduced invasiveness. The research hasprovidednovel knowledge on mechanical behavior of biomimicking needle devices under relevant conditions and will lead to development of reliable predictive needle-insertion models for robotics surgery. Overall, this research hasestablishedmechanics-based framework to design needling instrument with innovative biomimicking insertion mechanisms. Furthermore,this project has trained and educated the next generation of scientists and engineers by mentoring undergraduate and graduate students. This project has also attracted participation of underrepresented groups and women in STEM education and training by dissemination of the state-of-the-art knowledge to a broad range of audience including the general public and high school students through a variety of public forums such as technical conferences, science fairs, open house events, and summer programs.
